keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
keywords.name: glocations

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr., SIMON ROMERO and SABRINA TAVERNISE
byline.contributor: Donald G. McNeil Jr. reported from New York; Simon Romero from Recife, Brazil; and Sabrina Tavernise from Washington.

lead_paragraph: A sudden, sharp increase in babies with “no foreheads and very strange heads” was baffling doctors in Brazil. That set off a search for answers that led to a little-known pathogen, the Zika virus.

headline.print_headline: Medical Mystery With a Global Reach
headline.main: How a Medical Mystery in Brazil Led Doctors to Zika

snippet: A sudden, sharp increase in babies with “no foreheads and very strange heads” was baffling doctors in Brazil. That set off a search for answers that led to a little-known pathogen, the Zika virus.
abstract: Surge of microcephalic babies at Brazilian hospitals provided impetus for research that led to discovery of Zika virus sweeping country; questions remain over how virus was able to incubate in Brazil for nearly 70 years undetected and how best to respond.
